questions.question_text:
Your organization uses Active Directory to authenticate users. Users' Google account access must be removed when their Active Directory account is terminated.
How should your organization meet this requirement?

discussion.content:
D seems correct
https://cloud.google.com/architecture/identity/federating-gcp-with-active-directory-configuring-single-sign-on

Selected Answer: D
SSO allows for centralized user management, where user accounts and access permissions are managed in a single identity provider (such as Active Directory). When a user's Active Directory account is terminated, SSO provides a centralized point to revoke access across multiple applications and services, including Google accounts.

Selected Answer: D
of course the answer is D

Selected Answer: D
When you use SSO, you are redirected to an external Identity Provider. In this question, it is Microsoft AD. SAML assertion is sent to Google Cloud once the user is authenticated.
Answer is D

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
SSO is correct as deletion of AD account will remove access from GCP as well.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
D. Configure single sign-on in the Google domain

Selected Answer: D
Using SSO would help in removing access once the account is no longer active.

Selected Answer: D
Per Google Docs article, Federating Google Cloud with Active Directory. "This article describes how you can configure Cloud Identity or Google Workspace to use Active Directory as IdP and authoritative source.

The article compares the logical structure of Active Directory with the structure used by Cloud Identity and Google Workspace and describes how you can map Active Directory forests, domains, users, and groups. The article also provides a flowchart that helps you determine the best mapping approach for your scenario."
https://cloud.google.com/architecture/identity/federating-gcp-with-active-directory-introduction

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
SSO means federation between AD and Cloud ID, so is the correct answer
The correct answer should be "Setting up federation between Active Directory and Cloud Identity or Google Workspace". To do that, you have to enable automatic users provisioning and SSO.

Selected Answer: C
The question asked to provide a solution to remove users' Google account access when their Active Directory account is terminated. So, option 'C' should be correct as BeyondCorp and Identity Aware Proxy are focused solutions to mage Identity and implement a Zero trust model.

comments.content: The correct answer is D. If you have SSO configured, once a user's AD account is terminated, their access is removed from all services using AD.

discussion.content: Go for D

Selected Answer: D
Your organization uses Active Directory to authenticate users. 
Then you need to use Single sign-on (SSO) is an authentication scheme that allows a user to log in with a single ID and password to different systems and software.
SSO allows IT departments to administrator a single identity that can access many machines and cloud services.

Selected Answer: D
SSO is the answer

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
D is the answer

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D is correct
D is correct

Selected Answer: D
D. Configure single sign-on in the Google domain

choices.B: Remove the Google account from all IAM policies
choices.A: Configure two-factor authentication in the Google domain
choices.D: Configure single sign-on in the Google domain
choices.C: Configure BeyondCorp and Identity-Aware Proxy in the Google domain

questions.question_text: How is privacy defined in the context of cloud technology?

choices.A: Restrictions on data access and sharing
choices.C: Susceptibility to data breaches and cyber attacks

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I believe A and D are correct but I would say A because that is how most of Google Services allow you to define the privacy by restricting data access or sharing policies.
To me this is a general question, not just Google. Privacy defined by compliance standards makes more sense. A seems to be a general response to restrictions on data not specific to cloud technology.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A. Restrictions on data access and sharing

Privacy in the context of cloud technology is the protection of personal data from unauthorized access, use, or disclosure. This includes the right to control who has access to your data and how it is used.
A is right

Selected Answer: A
Privacy linked to data security

Selected Answer: A
What is Privacy? Privacy, in the context of cloud technology, refers to the data an organization or an individual has access to and who they can share that data with.

Selected Answer: D
Compliance with regulatory standards
A: Compliance with regulatory standards
D is correct
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
A is my answer.

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

Selected Answer: A
A seems to be correct answer.
A seems more correct. But why not D
key world is serverless = Cloud function

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

Selected Answer: B
B is correct.

Selected Answer: B
Only B is a serverless option.

Selected Answer: B
https://cloud.google.com/functions/docs/concepts/overview

Google Cloud Functions is a serverless execution environment for building and connecting cloud services. With Cloud Functions you write simple, single-purpose functions that are attached to events emitted from your cloud infrastructure and services.

Selected Answer: B
It is B the correct answer
Event driven functions... Cloud serverless

questions.question_text:
An organization wants to write and run small pieces of code in a serverless way that respond to events like huge discounts.
Which Google Cloud compute solution should the organization use?

choices.A: To replace the scanned documents with an online survey
choices.B: To ingest data in real time and encrypt unmatched words
choices.D: To transform the documents into unstructured data.
choices.C: To create digital versions of the documents and locate key information

questions.question_text:
An organization wants to search hundreds of scanned documents for key information like dates, names, and other specific words.
Why should the organization use application programming interfaces (APIs)?

discussion.content:
D is correct.
C is wrong because it says the data is in scanned documents, which means it is already digitalized.

comments.content: I think scanned documents and digital version of the documents are not the same. Scanned are only a picture of these documents, on the other hand the digital version of the documents are converted in Text and saved in format like PDF or any other common text formats.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Services like Natural Language API's scan the documents and extract entities which are unstructured data.

comments.content:
Leaning towards C since extracting key information seems to be the end goal. 
Why not D? Well scanned documents (images or PDFs) are already unstructured data, so you would transform unstructured data to unstructured data.

discussion.content: Very tricky

Selected Answer: C
The correct answer is C.
The organization can use APIs to connect to a document processing service that takes the scanned documents, convert them into digital text, and extract the key information that the organization is looking for.

Option D is not as effective for this task because it would make the documents even more difficult to search.

Selected Answer: C
I think the listed key details are not unstructured data. So D can't be the right answer me. Digitalized means OCR-ed document for me.

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
C. To create digital versions of the documents and locate key information

Application programming interfaces (APIs) can be used to create digital versions of scanned documents and locate key information within those documents. This is because APIs can be used to perform optical character recognition (OCR) on scanned documents. OCR is the process of converting scanned images of text into machine-readable text.

Selected Answer: C
Seems C is correct one. Making unstructured data is not making any sense here.

Selected Answer: D
Guys, D is correct. Think of it this way: the APIs are used to search for the data required in the documents (which are already digital btw). So the APIs are queried with the documents and not build on top of the documents. Hope that makes sense.

C. To create digital versions of the documents and locate key information: APIs can be used to interact with Optical Character Recognition (OCR) software and other document processing tools. These APIs can help convert scanned documents into digital, machine-readable formats and then extract specific information like dates, names, and keywords from them. This is a common use case for APIs when dealing with large volumes of scanned documents, as it allows for efficient data extraction and analysis.

I will go for C - This is referring to full text search, by digitalzing the scanned documents (scanned docs are already unstructured data and are not digitalized yet) and indexing them to make the search process easier.

Selected Answer: C
The organization should use application programming interfaces (APIs) to create digital versions of the scanned documents and locate key information. APIs can provide access to text recognition and document processing services, which can extract text from scanned documents and make it searchable. By utilizing APIs, the organization can convert the scanned documents into machine-readable formats, extract relevant information such as dates, names, and specific words, and perform searches efficiently. This enables the organization to easily locate and retrieve the desired information from a large volume of documents.

Question and the options are confusing or not proper. Vision API can detect text in PDF/TIFF files https://cloud.google.com/vision/docs/pdf. Hence I think the closest is C but it also says to convert it to digital document which already has been done.

Terrible question and choices. The answer is def not A or B which leaves C or D. The docs are already scanned (so not C) and why would they want to convert the docs to unstructured data when searching for "specific words"?

Selected Answer: C
APIs can be used to access and extract specific information from documents, including scanned documents. By using APIs, the organization can extract key information such as dates, names, and specific words from the scanned documents without manually reviewing each document. This can significantly reduce the time and effort required to search the documents for the desired information.
Additionally, APIs can be used to convert the scanned documents into digital versions, which can be easily searched and analyzed. Once the scanned documents are converted into digital versions, the organization can use APIs to extract the desired information and store it in a database or other system for further analysis.

Selected Answer: C
I chose C. I agree with one comment that the documents are scanned, so they are already digitized. But the question reads to me like the data is already unstructured. I do not like this question.

Selected Answer: C
APIs can be used to extract information from scanned documents and convert them into digital formats that can be searched and analyzed. APIs can help automate the process of locating key information, such as dates, names, and specific words, within hundreds of scanned documents, making it easier for the organization to find what they are looking for.

Selected Answer: D
Toss up, but lean D because of the "function" of an API

Selected Answer: C
c is correct
D is correct. The text from the PDF/scanned documents/images gets converted into JSON (unstructured file) which will be further used for search.
Very vague question & ambiguous choices.. it's a toss!! :)
D seems to be the right Answer

Go with D - Example - https://www.google.com/search?q=Use+of++API+to+analyse++Unstructure+data&sxsrf=ALiCzsZOh6qcSg7M5irKh-lDgAfcluNsWA%3A1665224285706&ei=XU5BY4DXKsqOz7sPkLCG4A0&ved=0ahUKEwjA-ZTws9D6AhVKx3MBHRCYAdwQ4dUDCA4&uact=5&oq=Use+of++API+to+analyse++Unstructure+data&gs_lcp=Cgdnd3Mtd2l6EAMyCgghEMMEEAoQoAE6CggAEEcQ1gQQsAM6BQgAEKIEOgQIIRAKSgQITRgBSgQIQRgASgQIRhgAUMsFWJ0wYLMzaANwAXgAgAHNAYgBwROSAQYwLjE0LjGYAQCgAQHIAQjAAQE&sclient=gws-wiz

MonkeyLearn is API used for Unstructure Data.

Selected Answer: D
I am with d To transform the documents into unstructured data.

Selected Answer: C
C seems to be the answer
